Title: Chapter Six
Subtitle: A Past Outgrown
Synopsis: Cody tries not to feel left behind.
Body:
"Since you started on your first day, you haven't been drug tested. What's gonna change their mind on Monday, bro? My work never runs drug tests," he says. Gunfire cracks over the TV, flashing the empty walls with pops of color.

 "No shit, Miguel. Their corporate structure banks on baked box-boys like you. The ones that forget they're lifting crates and stocking shelves and selling printers for eight hours a day."

 "That's manager Miguel now — I order the little guys to do it. I'm a number-puncher like you now," He brags. "Oh. But except I'm actually good enough to get promoted."

 The words hit at the same time as a round-ending enemy airstrike. The bombs collapse my soldier to the dirt as the word DEFEAT brandishes across the screens, reassuring us that "we'll get them next time." But his quips hurt no more than the vibrations in the controller.

  Miguel cracks another lukewarm beer, kicking the box of the remaining 27 over to me. I put down my custom controller.

  "I get bringing over a six-pack of some IPA, maybe a 12-pack of Coors or something, but thirty?"

 He manages a straight face as his brown eyes pierce mine, wiping the suds from his scruffy lip rug. "You know, Jesus was wrong when he said 'man can't live on bread alone.' He didn't know you could drink it yet."

 "Is that right?" I laugh.

 "They've been rolling around the back of my car for a couple weeks after going to Katy's house. You know, high school Katy?"

 "No?"

  "The pregnancy scare one, with the nice—."

 "Yeah, no — I remember," I say. Her face flashes in my mind from our junior prom group. Miguel took her while I took Kei.

 "Well, I took her friend home and stole the thirty-rack since no one touched it. Those guys are all fuckin' hipsters, man, so far up their ass about IPA's and stuff, they won't drink just to get drunk anymore."

 "Coming from the guy who doesn't smoke just to get high," I tell him. "Passionate stoners are worse than drinkers. You couldn't be any more uninteresting when you're talking about 'Sour Dee' or whatever," I say.

 "Fuck off."

 He burps. I crack another warm one, and when the timer on the pre-game lobby counts to zero, I lift my controller again. But he hits me with something that isn't just a snide comeback.

 "Do you miss high school?" He asks.

 It takes me a moment to think. I haven't really considered it, though I've noticed myself staying away from those places we hung out between classes and after school. Those places have some gravity I'm afraid will get me sucked into that past, when I've worked so hard to put those good times behind me.

 "I dunno. It's like a friend you haven't seen in a while. Nice to visit every once in a while and relish in the past. But it's best for both of us if we move on, you know?"

 He drops the controller into his lap. My thumbs dig into the sticks when I climb a ladder for a sniper nest, only to get blasted off by a camper.

 "You trying to say something?"

 "No, dude," I start. "I—"

 "You can use that losing take on Kei or Kylie all you want, but on your friend?"

 "No, of course not! No, man. You're my best friend. You-"

 "I'm messing with you, fucker," he says.

 He laughs, swigging the rest of his beer between deaths.

 He says, "I do. I mean, a part of me does. I hated high school until the end of junior year when our group really started to hang out. It's like, I never felt like I was a part of something until then. And . . . I don't know if I really felt it since."

 "Yeah. I wonder what the others are up to," I ask.

 "Kayla's having her second kid already. Another girl, I think. Her and Johnny Boy are still together."

 "I was surprised. Getting married half a year after high school? I didn't think they'd make it this far."

 "You never went to their wedding, though."

 "I was in college halfway across the country, bud," I say.

 "How about Kei?" He asks. "You were trying to get with her for a while, but you never had the cajones to do it before she graduated after our junior year."

 "I've told you before," I say. "She's at my work."

 "No shit!" He laughs. "Puta madre, the yellow thirst was real for you, man." He cracks another can after getting mowed down by an LMG. "Are you gonna shoot your shot? You told me you got some experience in college, right?"

 "Yeah. But I don't know..." none of those nights in college really fulfilled me. I was always missing something. "I'm not into the clubbing scene like you are."

 "All you have to do is ask! It's not like high school. Alcohol changes things. The fellas I met in college showed me all around the city. I know that shit like the front of my hand!"

 "Back. The back of your hand," I say.

 "Whatever. But we need to get you laid, now that you got this fine house. Shit, man, I wish I could afford something like this. People our age probably never will."

 "But you still live here in Hearthland Ridge," I say.

 "Paying for a studio! Like living in a fuckin' box for seventeen hundred a month," he says. "Walls so paper-thin I can hear everything. I'd rather go out and get some pussy than cuck myself to the soundtrack of someone else getting it."

 "Uh, sure," I say — sometimes I wonder if he tries to fit as many of those words as he can into a sentence.

 "But really. I'm proud of you, man," he tells me. "Really. You've worked hard and you've made it. When I was trying to work my way through our senior class, you were grinding at math and shit. You have an actual chance to get wifed up. It's not in my blood."

 "What do you mean?" I ask.

 "Well, I don't want to. I like the chase better, you know. Settling down? That's like giving up. What do you do, then? With that feeling, you know, when you have a couple rats with some chick and you know you're locked in for the next forever?"

 The feeling's all I've been able to think about since I got back here. No more regimentation. No convenient road map of class to class to graduation: now it's all just open-ended.

 "But, like, nothing against you if you're into that. Having rats can be dope. They mow your lawn and shit."

 "Someday. Maybe. I'm just too boring, I think," I say.

 "Boring? You were the heart of our group back then, dude. You brought us together. You're good at that."

 "But nothing's forcing any of us to be together anymore," I say. "Look at how many have moved away from here. It's just you and me now, right?"

 "Kayla and John are in California. Michael went to Kansas. He likes flat woman, so I guess he wants a state that can get him off just by driving on the roads."

 The beer comes up my nose. I drop the controller and the batteries pop out. "Ugh. Fuck, man," I say, balancing the pain of carbonation in my nose with the urge to laugh, imagining Mike trying to stick his wiener in a Kansas anthill.

 Miguel says, "Maybe we'll be stuck here forever. But hey, as long as we're both here."

 "I just wish . . ." I start to say, but instead, I reach down and pop the batteries back in the controller.

 He slicks his hair back again, finishing another one. "Is it cool if I crash here? I mean, I can drive high, but not drunk."

 "Sure, man. But I don't have a cot or a sleeping bag or anything."

 "Please. I've slept on floors my whole adult life!" He gestures to the box with 23 stones left. "Now are you gonna help me finish all of them?"

 "All of them?"

 "All of them," he says. "It's Friday. I know we're old and shit now, but stay awake a little longer, like we're twelve and it's a sleepover in your parents' basement, and I'll tell you a bedtime story."

 "Oh, great. About what?"

 "One time I was playing on your Xbox when you were out of town. When you had me pet-sitting, and..."

 "I'll pass. But—" I think, as long as I'm not drinking alone, it can't hurt. What's the worst that can happen?

"No, I get what you're saying, but what do you mean?" Miguel says, slurring his words as he melts into the futon: the only piece of furniture our drunk asses could assemble. The overturned boxes are makeshift tables that keep the cans off the floor, since we're feeling too lazy to dig for a trash bag.

 I lift the can to my lips, but I don't let the poison pass the threshold. Past experience tells me that I'm toeing my limit: lost enough to let my stupid emotions leak on my face, to conjure words to try to push them down, but not enough to kneel at the porcelain throne. I know the feeling is real because the wetness on my face gives it credence, and I often think he's the only friend I've got left to listen.

 If only I could get him to.

 "How can you get it if you don't know what I mean?" I ask.

 "I get it, bro, just not what you mean." Miguel lifts the cracked smartphone above his face as he lays on the futon, thumb-scrolling through an endless barrage of ads and entertainment.

 "What I mean is that I don't feel it anymore. My life is just work, then sleep, then work, then go to sleep, but it's nothing more than that. I don't have it like you do. You always have the energy, but I don't know how you find it." The tears leak further: I can't remember the last time I was drunk enough to let them out. "But I know the time is in between there somewhere, I mean, I'm certain I could fit in anything if I tried. But I'm always just so damn tired."

 He swipes right a couple times in a dating app, still refusing to look up. "Time isn't the only thing that's too small of yours to fit." He laughs. Then the vibration from a match startles him.

 Miguel's thumb slips and he flings his phone in the air, letting out a grunt when it crashes into his nose.He jolts upright to rub the pain out, looking at me for the first time in an hour.

 "Oh, shit. You're serious."

 "Yeah, you think this is just a bit?"

 "No, of course not." He sets his phone on a cardboard box and thinks for a moment. "Why I 'feel it.' I don't know . . . I guess I just got a big family that always keeps me busy. My cousins are young, and my siblings are still in college, so I end up going to their parties and stuff."

 "So it's like college never ended for you. Never realized I'd miss it so much . . . my roommates made the damn experience," I say. It didn't matter if we were in the dorms or slumming it in an expensive renter-fixer-upper west of campus: those fuckers forced me to get out. "Most nights, when I was studying in my bedroom, nose stuck in a textbook, they'd pick the lock and barge in — shooting me with flaming Nerf darts, assaulting me with a pizza cutter, or dragging me to one of their parties."

 He takes the last swig of his seventh can. "Just like my older cousins. They show up to my house to drag me clubbing, even if I pulled a 'tenner' at work."

 "Man. If my brother was still around, I'm sure he'd be over here all the time," I say.

 "Of course. Our families had a lot of fun together: barbeques, parties at the park..." The list trails off when he crunches the can in his hands.

 "You remember those weekends in middle school when we tried to beat the Halo campaign in a single night?"

 "Yeah. And your brother would buy all those energy drinks, sneaking them downstairs for us," he says. "Oh, and the summer tent sleepovers, remember that one night you were so scared of the lightning you couldn't move, and my dad had to carry you back inside?"

 "I was stuck in the sleeping bag, so soaking wet from the rain I almost slid out of his arms," I say. We share a laugh. "Or the RV trip we took for the out-of-state Lacrosse game—when we got stuck on the side of the road. We used up all the power playing GameCube and my dad was furious!"

 He laughs. "Yeah. And we had to ask one of the families running behind to pick us up. The whole time we waited there, your dad was screaming at Triple-A, and your mom was trying to cook, but the RV tipped so far to the side that she couldn't set anything on the counter..."

 "...And all we could do was just pass the ball on the side of the road, wondering whether or not we were gonna make the game."

 "But we won that one, right?"

 "Yeah — I ripped the game-winning corner pocket."

 "Oh yeah. Their team was trash. The goalie scored on himself."

 The nostalgia can only abate the emptiness for so long. I take another swig, feeling the body high mix with the dizziness from the flat beer. Without them, the next words might not have left me.

 "But now it's just like . . . I dunno. I only know that it sucks, you know?"

 "Of course."

 "Like, I'm trying to care, but I don't. My mind doesn't want me to be happy." I nearly fall out of the folding chair when I'm talking with my arms. "We're not forced to get out there anymore. To meet new people, to keep friendships alive. All our friends are getting married or serious while we're just left behind. My parents nag me about it all the time: getting impatient since I'm the only one left that'll keep the family name going. And—""That shit doesn't matter. That's not what it's about," Miguel says. "You just gotta do, man. You gotta do things just to do them."

 I furrow my brows. "To do what?"

 He wets his lips on a last sip before he tries at something profound.

 "The doing is what makes happiness come, when even . . . even when you're, like, not happy, and shit, you force yourself to do things, so happy shit can happen more often and shit, so you can have the chance to enjoy it," he insists.

 I'm lost without words, so he decides to muddy the waters even further.

 "You get the gist of what I'm saying? Like, you have to decide to do no matter what. Like even when you don't feel like it, you know, you do. The doing, I mean, is something you choose which gives a chance of something good. Or something, at least. You know?"I feel like I just had a seizure. "What the fuck does that even mean?"

 "I don't know, man. Maybe I'm bad at . . . no, maybe you suck at listening," he says. "I said that shit perfectly."

 I mutter to myself, trying to piece together what he said. It takes me a couple seconds. "Force yourself to engage with the world. Give happiness its best chance to come out, because it's all you can do."

 "That's exactly what I said!" He snatches another can, using the light of the TV to inspect all the dents from rolling around in his Corolla.

 "Like hell you did!" I roll my eyes.

 His verbal seizure must have made him tired. He puts the can down instead of cracking another one, and after a long yawn, he pulls the unzipped sleeping bag off the floor and wraps it around himself on the futon."That thing goes down flat, you know," I offer. "It doesn't have to be a couch."

 "Too much effort. I've slept on worse," he says. "I gotta get to sleep so I can make it to church tomorrow."

 "And show up hungover? I doubt you'll make it through the service," I say. "But, hey, if you stay a while after, I'm sure you could catch the double-A meeting."

 He's too tired for a clap-back. He's not even scrolling his phone anymore: just sprawled there with his feet dangling over the wobbly armrest, arms tucked beneath him, his face buried into a folded towel.

 I glance at the stove. "It's only like 12:30."

 "Long day . . . leading idiots . . . feels so late," he says, turning to bury his face in the leather crevice of the couch.

 "So much for an all-nighter, huh?"

 "Nnnn," he mumbles into the towel. "Guessn't."

 "I guess we're not young anymore," I say. "We didn't even make it through half the rack."

 "Nn."

 "So are we gonna finish these?"

 No answer.

 "I said..."

 But then I give up.

"And show up hungover? I doubt you'll make it through the service," I say. "But, hey, if you stay a while after, I'm sure you could catch the double-A meeting."

He's too tired for a clap-back. He's not even scrolling his phone anymore: just sprawled there with his feet dangling over the wobbly armrest, arms tucked beneath him, his face buried into a folded towel.
I glance at the stove. "It's only like 12:30."
"Long day . . . leading idiots . . . feels so late," he says, turning to bury his face in the leather crevice of the couch.
"So much for an all-nighter, huh?"
"Nnnn," he mumbles into the towel. "Guessn't."
"I guess we're not young anymore," I say. "We didn't even make it through half the rack."
"Nn."
"So are we gonna finish these?"
No answer.
"I said..."
But then I give up.
